values.description:
* gazebo-default-sdformat-default: split packages onto separate lines, remove whitespace at end of lines

* but don't install libsdformatN-dev

The [builds are failing to find libsdformat4-dev](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/57/console), but we probably don't even want to install an sdformat package.
values.title: gazebo-any-sdformat-any: don't install sdformat package

summary.raw:
* gazebo-default-sdformat-default: split packages onto separate lines, remove whitespace at end of lines

* but don't install libsdformatN-dev

The [builds are failing to find libsdformat4-dev](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/57/console), but we probably don't even want to install an sdformat package.
summary.html:
• gazebo-default-sdformat-default: split packages onto separate lines, remove whitespace at end of lines

  • but don't install libsdformatN-dev

The builds are failing to find libsdformat4-dev, but we probably don't even want to install an sdformat package.

values.description:
What is implemented:

 * Pull request any scripts (-pr-any-) in Linux, Windows y OsX
 * ABI checker triggered automatically from -pr-any- when needed
 * All default jobs for all the supported branches in Linux, Windows y OsX
 * debbuild jobs for all major supported branches

There are still some pieces missing, like coverage, but I will send it in the next PR

values.description:
The problem was the the remove command was deleting all the publishers section what included the test results exportation.

I did not find the way of do that since the the following command do nothing:
```
         project.remove(project / publishers / 'hudson.plugins.emailext.ExtendedEmailPublisher')
```

I implemented an update_field command and get the same effect by using a combination of calls.
values.title: Fix ANY test results

summary.raw:
The problem was the the remove command was deleting all the publishers section what included the test results exportation.

I did not find the way of do that since the the following command do nothing:
```
         project.remove(project / publishers / 'hudson.plugins.emailext.ExtendedEmailPublisher')
```

I implemented an update_field command and get the same effect by using a combination of calls.
summary.html:
The problem was the the remove command was deleting all the publishers section what included the test results exportation.

I did not find the way of do that since the the following command do nothing:

         project.remove(project / publishers / 'hudson.plugins.emailext.ExtendedEmailPublisher')

I implemented an update_field command and get the same effect by using a combination of calls.

values.description:
This is the first PR of the brew bottle creation integrated into the release.py and implementing the following workflow:

```
 - release.py
 -> update tarball hash in formula (generic-release-homebrew_pull_request_updater) [not in this PR, already implemented]
    -> build bottle (generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder)
          -> upload bottle to S3 (repository_uploader) 
          -> update bottle hash in formula (generic-release-homebrew_pr_bottle_hash_updater)
```
Testing runs:

 * [Bottle builder](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/37/)
 * [Bottle hash update](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/generic-release-homebrew_pr_bottle_hash_updater/25/)

It currently creates two different pull requests to update hashes. @scpeters mentioned that we will need to commit the second modification in the first pull request open. I've leave this for a next pull request, I still need to figure out how to hack this.
values.title: Brew bottles creation and hash updating

summary.raw:
This is the first PR of the brew bottle creation integrated into the release.py and implementing the following workflow:

```
 - release.py
 -> update tarball hash in formula (generic-release-homebrew_pull_request_updater) [not in this PR, already implemented]
    -> build bottle (generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder)
          -> upload bottle to S3 (repository_uploader) 
          -> update bottle hash in formula (generic-release-homebrew_pr_bottle_hash_updater)
```
Testing runs:

 * [Bottle builder](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder/37/)
 * [Bottle hash update](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/generic-release-homebrew_pr_bottle_hash_updater/25/)

It currently creates two different pull requests to update hashes. @scpeters mentioned that we will need to commit the second modification in the first pull request open. I've leave this for a next pull request, I still need to figure out how to hack this.
summary.html:
This is the first PR of the brew bottle creation integrated into the release.py and implementing the following workflow:

 - release.py
 -> update tarball hash in formula (generic-release-homebrew_pull_request_updater) [not in this PR, already implemented]
    -> build bottle (generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder)
          -> upload bottle to S3 (repository_uploader) 
          -> update bottle hash in formula (generic-release-homebrew_pr_bottle_hash_updater)

Testing runs:

  • Bottle builder
  • Bottle hash update

It currently creates two different pull requests to update hashes. @scpeters mentioned that we will need to commit the second modification in the first pull request open. I've leave this for a next pull request, I still need to figure out how to hack this.

values.description:
Implement osX detection and brew installation in the one line script. This should make the Linux and osX installation instructions to converge in one single line.

It also implements a testing script, but we need to merge this PR before being able to run the script from default branch. I was testing it manually on t1000.

TODO: check for supported versions when filling the dist_version. @scpeters?
values.title: Implement brew installation in one-line script

summary.raw:
Implement osX detection and brew installation in the one line script. This should make the Linux and osX installation instructions to converge in one single line.

It also implements a testing script, but we need to merge this PR before being able to run the script from default branch. I was testing it manually on t1000.

TODO: check for supported versions when filling the dist_version. @scpeters?
summary.html:
Implement osX detection and brew installation in the one line script. This should make the Linux and osX installation instructions to converge in one single line.

It also implements a testing script, but we need to merge this PR before being able to run the script from default branch. I was testing it manually on t1000.

TODO: check for supported versions when filling the dist_version. @scpeters?

values.description:
This PRs should help with fixing problems with apt repositories and our squid proxy:

 * Try to detect if squid proxy is running when starting the job and if it is not, start it.
 * Move the squid detection part in docker to be after cache invalidating so we always get a non-cached result but a real checking.
values.title: Improve squid proxy detection and start

summary.raw:
This PRs should help with fixing problems with apt repositories and our squid proxy:

 * Try to detect if squid proxy is running when starting the job and if it is not, start it.
 * Move the squid detection part in docker to be after cache invalidating so we always get a non-cached result but a real checking.
summary.html:
This PRs should help with fixing problems with apt repositories and our squid proxy:

  • Try to detect if squid proxy is running when starting the job and if it is not, start it.
  • Move the squid detection part in docker to be after cache invalidating so we always get a non-cached result but a real checking.

values.description:
Two problems are fixed in this PR:

 * The DSL generation was using ign_transport for all the abicheckers instead of select the proper one for each ignition package. Fixed using a map.
 * To check if we need to call the abichecker we need to define `DEST_BRANCH` variable although is not used in the build script at all. This variable is sent by our bitjen daemon (bitbucket <-> jenkins). I've moved it from individual jobs to OSRFLionuxCompilationAny class.
values.title: Fix problem with ignition abichecking

summary.raw:
Two problems are fixed in this PR:

 * The DSL generation was using ign_transport for all the abicheckers instead of select the proper one for each ignition package. Fixed using a map.
 * To check if we need to call the abichecker we need to define `DEST_BRANCH` variable although is not used in the build script at all. This variable is sent by our bitjen daemon (bitbucket <-> jenkins). I've moved it from individual jobs to OSRFLionuxCompilationAny class.
summary.html:
Two problems are fixed in this PR:

  • The DSL generation was using ign_transport for all the abicheckers instead of select the proper one for each ignition package. Fixed using a map.
  • To check if we need to call the abichecker we need to define DEST_BRANCH variable although is not used in the build script at all. This variable is sent by our bitjen daemon (bitbucket <-> jenkins). I've moved it from individual jobs to OSRFLionuxCompilationAny class.

values.description:
I just fixed all our homebrew bottles, which were broken due to a boost update. The [gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64/) job has been passing though because we don't test the installation. This just adds a `brew test` command after `brew install` which should catch most failures.

~~Here's a [build with this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64/26/)~~

Update: that build won't work because it pull the one_liner script from the default branch. We can test this after it's merged.
values.title: brew test one_liner script to verify bottles are working

summary.raw:
I just fixed all our homebrew bottles, which were broken due to a boost update. The [gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64/) job has been passing though because we don't test the installation. This just adds a `brew test` command after `brew install` which should catch most failures.

~~Here's a [build with this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64/26/)~~

Update: that build won't work because it pull the one_liner script from the default branch. We can test this after it's merged.
summary.html:
I just fixed all our homebrew bottles, which were broken due to a boost update. The gazebo-install-one_liner-homebrew-amd64 job has been passing though because we don't test the installation. This just adds a brew test command after brew install which should catch most failures.

Here's a build with this branch

Update: that build won't work because it pull the one_liner script from the default branch. We can test this after it's merged.

values.description:
Two different clients:

**1. command line parameters:**
`./set_pr_status.py --user <bitbucket_user> --pass <bitbucket_name> --repository_name="_jrivero_/sdformat" --sha="3b518d9" --status='ok' --jenkins_job_name="gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none" --jenkins_build_url="http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/"`

[bitbucket result](https://bitbucket.org/_jrivero_/sdformat/pull-requests/5/add-attribute-to-to-specify-which-frame-to/commits)

**2. load config from file**

`./set_status_from_file.py --user <bitbucket_user> --pass <bitbucket_pass> --status inprogress --load_from_file pr.yaml`

[bitbucket result](https://bitbucket.org/_jrivero_/sdformat/pull-requests/2/add-sdf-definitions-for-gps-sensor-sensor/commits)
values.title: Bitbucket python client to set build status

summary.raw:
Two different clients:

**1. command line parameters:**
`./set_pr_status.py --user <bitbucket_user> --pass <bitbucket_name> --repository_name="_jrivero_/sdformat" --sha="3b518d9" --status='ok' --jenkins_job_name="gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none" --jenkins_build_url="http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/"`

[bitbucket result](https://bitbucket.org/_jrivero_/sdformat/pull-requests/5/add-attribute-to-to-specify-which-frame-to/commits)

**2. load config from file**

`./set_status_from_file.py --user <bitbucket_user> --pass <bitbucket_pass> --status inprogress --load_from_file pr.yaml`

[bitbucket result](https://bitbucket.org/_jrivero_/sdformat/pull-requests/2/add-sdf-definitions-for-gps-sensor-sensor/commits)
summary.html:
Two different clients:

1. command line parameters: ./set_pr_status.py --user <bitbucket_user> --pass <bitbucket_name> --repository_name="_jrivero_/sdformat" --sha="3b518d9" --status='ok' --jenkins_job_name="gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none" --jenkins_build_url="http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/"

bitbucket result

2. load config from file

./set_status_from_file.py --user <bitbucket_user> --pass <bitbucket_pass> --status inprogress --load_from_file pr.yaml

bitbucket result

summary.html:
This is minor, but it removes an un-necessary step in the homebrew_formula_pullrequest script by using the latest version of hub.

Tested here:

values.description:
When using a non-standard version number (such as 0.9.0~pre1 from https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/81 ), homebrew doesn't always detect it properly. For example, instead of `0.9.0~pre1` homebrew identified version `1`. I've added some logic to detect when the auto-generated version is incorrect and add an explicit version tag in that case.

Tested in:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/generic-release-homebrew_pull_request_updater/44
* https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/82
values.title: Homebrew formula PR: detect when auto-detected version is incorrect

Tested in:

values.description:
Script to use the python client to send the 'in progress' status to bitbucket.

[Tested on a new PR](https://bitbucket.org/_jrivero_/sdformat/pull-requests/18/issue_8_2_scpeters/diff) sent against my fork of sdformat.

Before accepting the PR when need to think about how to handle the packages that did not setup the bitbucket status via bitbucket_osrf user.

Script to use the python client to send the 'in progress' status to bitbucket.

Tested on a new PR sent against my fork of sdformat.

Before accepting the PR when need to think about how to handle the packages that did not setup the bitbucket status via bitbucket_osrf user.

values.description: Our debbuild jobs needs to know about which repositories to use when building packages. This PR implements a new parameter in the buildsystem that is usually filled from release.py which add logic about which repositories are self contained and which are used in combination with stable.
values.title: Implement a parameter to set which OSRF repos to use when building

summary.raw: Our debbuild jobs needs to know about which repositories to use when building packages. This PR implements a new parameter in the buildsystem that is usually filled from release.py which add logic about which repositories are self contained and which are used in combination with stable.

values.description:
Tow main actions in this pull request:

  * Refactor the code than handles the set status so it can be called several times
  * jenkins DSL code to call status after build

I made some tests:

  *  [The testing job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64_test_status_postbuild_tasks/). The last three builds are on different commits: success, failure or unstable.
  * The commits build results can be checked [here](https://bitbucket.org/_jrivero_/sdformat/commits/all)

If you want to play with a testing job that has this implementation, I just copy what the DSL generates here: http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64_test_pr_buildstatus
values.title: Implement the publish of post-build status in bitbucket

values.title: quick fix for broken jobs

values.description:
When running a test multiple times, a flaky test will sometimes pass and sometimes fail. Some build tools (such as [maven](https://github.com/apache/maven-surefire/commit/fefaae7f0534a59f52c046a64c96987e8561dd48)) have been adding support for reporting flaky test failures in junit xml files using a `<flakyFailure>` element instead of a `<failure>` element. I've [requested this feature for gtest](https://github.com/google/googletest/issues/727), but in the meantime, I've written a python script that reads two junit files and writes a merged junit file with `<failure>` tags converted to `<flakyFailure>` tags.

I've also attached some example junit files taken from results of an intentionally flaky test (see [ign-math d22d516a03](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/d22d516a038c2aa691b569b3386322c738a1c6c7?at=flaky_rand_test)).

~~~
python flaky_junit_merge.py flaky_xml/input1.xml flaky_xml/input2.xml > flaky_xml/output12.xml
python flaky_junit_merge.py flaky_xml/input2.xml flaky_xml/input1.xml > flaky_xml/output21.xml
~~~

I'll make a PR for integrating with build scripts later. In the meantime, here's a sneak peak of jenkins reporting of flaky tests:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/45/testReport/(root)/
values.title: Add script for merging junit xml files to identify flaky test failures, along with example xml

summary.raw:
When running a test multiple times, a flaky test will sometimes pass and sometimes fail. Some build tools (such as [maven](https://github.com/apache/maven-surefire/commit/fefaae7f0534a59f52c046a64c96987e8561dd48)) have been adding support for reporting flaky test failures in junit xml files using a `<flakyFailure>` element instead of a `<failure>` element. I've [requested this feature for gtest](https://github.com/google/googletest/issues/727), but in the meantime, I've written a python script that reads two junit files and writes a merged junit file with `<failure>` tags converted to `<flakyFailure>` tags.

I've also attached some example junit files taken from results of an intentionally flaky test (see [ign-math d22d516a03](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/d22d516a038c2aa691b569b3386322c738a1c6c7?at=flaky_rand_test)).

~~~
python flaky_junit_merge.py flaky_xml/input1.xml flaky_xml/input2.xml > flaky_xml/output12.xml
python flaky_junit_merge.py flaky_xml/input2.xml flaky_xml/input1.xml > flaky_xml/output21.xml
~~~

I'll make a PR for integrating with build scripts later. In the meantime, here's a sneak peak of jenkins reporting of flaky tests:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/45/testReport/(root)/
summary.html:
When running a test multiple times, a flaky test will sometimes pass and sometimes fail. Some build tools (such as maven) have been adding support for reporting flaky test failures in junit xml files using a <flakyFailure> element instead of a <failure> element. I've requested this feature for gtest, but in the meantime, I've written a python script that reads two junit files and writes a merged junit file with <failure> tags converted to <flakyFailure> tags.

I've also attached some example junit files taken from results of an intentionally flaky test (see ign-math d22d516a03).

python flaky_junit_merge.py flaky_xml/input1.xml flaky_xml/input2.xml > flaky_xml/output12.xml
python flaky_junit_merge.py flaky_xml/input2.xml flaky_xml/input1.xml > flaky_xml/output21.xml

I'll make a PR for integrating with build scripts later. In the meantime, here's a sneak peak of jenkins reporting of flaky tests:

  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/45/testReport/(root)/

values.description:
Some Ubuntu distributions (Trusty and before) ships lower versions of python support (requests) than then ones required to work with our python script. I moved the installation from packages to pip.

Tested here: http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/44/ and here: http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_math-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/45/
values.title: Use pip to install python support for bibucket client
